# Military funerals in the United States

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/53/SMA_Dunway_Burial_at_Arlington_National_Cemetery_2008.jpg/325px-
SMA_Dunway_Burial_at_Arlington_National_Cemetery_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:SMA_Dunway_Burial_at_Arlington_National_Cemetery_2008.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SMA_Dunway_Burial_at_Arlington_National_Cemetery_2008.jpg
"Enlarge")

The United States Army Caisson Platoon of the [3rd United States Infantry
Regiment "The Old Guard"](/wiki/3d_US_Infantry_Regiment_\(The_Old_Guard\) "3d
US Infantry Regiment \(The Old Guard\)") transports the flag-draped casket of
[Sergeant Major of the Army](/wiki/Sergeant_Major_of_the_Army "Sergeant Major
of the Army") [George W. Dunaway](/wiki/George_W._Dunaway "George W. Dunaway")
on a horse-drawn [limbers and caissons](/wiki/Limbers_and_caissons "Limbers
and caissons") during a military funeral procession at [Arlington National
Cemetery](/wiki/Arlington_National_Cemetery "Arlington National Cemetery"),
2008.

A **military funeral in the United States** is a memorial or burial rite given
by the U.S. [military](/wiki/Military "Military") for a
[Soldier](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army"),
[Marine](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps"),
[Sailor](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy"), [Coast
Guardsman](/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United States Coast Guard"), or
[Airman](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force") who died in
battle, a [veteran](/wiki/Veteran "Veteran"), or other prominent military
figures or a president. A military [funeral](/wiki/Funeral "Funeral") may
feature [guards of honor](/wiki/Honor_guard "Honor guard"), the firing of
[volley shots](/wiki/3-volley_salute "3-volley salute") as a salute, drumming
and other military elements, with a [flag](/wiki/Flag "Flag") draping over the
[coffin](/wiki/Coffin "Coffin").

In the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"), the [United
States Army Military District of
Washington](/wiki/United_States_Army_Military_District_of_Washington "United
States Army Military District of Washington") (MDW) is responsible for
providing military funerals. "Honoring Those Who Served" is the title of the
program for instituting a dignified military funeral with full honors to the
nation's veterans.

As of January 1, 2000, Section 578 of Public Law 106-65 of the [National
Defense Authorization Act](/wiki/National_Defense_Authorization_Act "National
Defense Authorization Act") mandates that the [United States Armed
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces") shall
provide the rendering of honors in a military funeral for any eligible veteran
if requested by his or her family. As mandated by federal law, an [honor
guard](/wiki/Honor_guard "Honor guard") detail for the burial of an eligible
veteran shall consist of no fewer than two members of the Armed Forces. One
member of the detail shall be a representative of the parent armed service of
the deceased veteran. The honor guard detail will, at a minimum, perform a
ceremony that includes the folding and presenting of the [flag of the United
States](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States "Flag of the United States") to the
[next of kin](/wiki/Next_of_kin "Next of kin") and the playing of
_[Taps](/wiki/Taps "Taps")_ which will be played by a [lone
bugler](/wiki/Bugle_\(instrument\) "Bugle \(instrument\)"), if available, or
by [audio recording](/wiki/Audio_recording "Audio recording"). Today, there
are so few buglers available that the United States Armed Forces often cannot
provide one.[1] However, federal law allows
[Reserve](/wiki/Reserve_Component_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_United_States
"Reserve Component of the Armed Forces of the United States") and [National
Guard](/wiki/United_States_National_Guard "United States National Guard")
units to assist with funeral honors duty when necessary.

##
Eligibility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_funerals_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Eligibility")]

See also: [United States Department of Veterans
Affairs](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Veterans_Affairs "United States
Department of Veterans Affairs") and [United States National
Cemetery](/wiki/United_States_National_Cemetery "United States National
Cemetery")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Barrow_RobertH_GenUSMC_Funeral_20081103-M-8689P-003.JPG/225px-
Barrow_RobertH_GenUSMC_Funeral_20081103-M-8689P-003.JPG)](/wiki/File:Barrow_RobertH_GenUSMC_Funeral_20081103-M-8689P-003.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Barrow_RobertH_GenUSMC_Funeral_20081103-M-8689P-003.JPG
"Enlarge")

A [military chaplain](/wiki/Military_chaplain "Military chaplain") seen
leading honor guards derived from the [United States Marine
Corps](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps") as they
carry the casket of General [Robert H. Barrow](/wiki/Robert_H._Barrow "Robert
H. Barrow") to the place of burial.

Generally, federal law allows for military funeral honors for all veterans who
were [discharged](/wiki/Military_discharge "Military discharge") under
circumstances "other than [dishonorable](/wiki/Military_discharge#Dishonorable
"Military discharge")." Funeral directors will require the veteran's [DD Form
214](/wiki/DD_Form_214 "DD Form 214") to establish eligibility.[2]

Those who are eligible for military funerals and full honors in the United
States include the following:[3]

  * [Active duty](/wiki/Active_duty "Active duty") or [Selected Reserve](/wiki/Selected_Reserve "Selected Reserve") in the United States Armed Forces.
  * Former active duty or Selected Reserve who departed under conditions other than dishonorable in the United States Armed Forces.
  * Former [enlisted](/wiki/Enlisted_rank "Enlisted rank") servicemen or servicewomen who completed at least one term or period of initial obligated service in the Selected Reserve and departed under conditions other than dishonorable.
  * Former servicemen or servicewomen who were discharged due to a disability incurred or aggravated in the line of duty.

##
Ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_funerals_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Ceremony")]

See also: [Arlington Ladies](/wiki/Arlington_Ladies "Arlington Ladies") and

[](/wiki/File:US_Navy_040224-N-6213R-007_Members_of_the_U.S._Forces_Honor_Guard_march_during_the_funeral_for_retired_Adm._Thomas_H._Moorer.jpg
"Enlarge")

Escort platoons marching during the military funeral of Admiral [Thomas Hinman
Moorer](/wiki/Thomas_Hinman_Moorer "Thomas Hinman Moorer") in Arlington
National Cemetery, 2004.

In the United States, there are several types of military funerals such as
those performed at Arlington National Cemetery, which include and omit certain
components depending on the status of the deceased (active, retired,
[veteran](/wiki/Veteran "Veteran"), [rank](/wiki/Military_rank "Military
rank")/occupation).[4]

**Standard honor** military funerals include the following:

  * A [military chaplain](/wiki/United_States_military_chaplains "United States military chaplains") for family members.
  * A casket draped in the [flag of the United States](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States "Flag of the United States") and as a [pall](/wiki/Pall_\(funeral\) "Pall \(funeral\)").
  * A casket team serving as [honor guards](/wiki/Honor_guard "Honor guard") in a ceremonial role over the remains and as [pallbearers](/wiki/Pallbearer "Pallbearer").
  * For funerals for an enlisted [non-commissioned officer](/wiki/Non-commissioned_officer#United_States "Non-commissioned officer") of E-9 and Officers, the casket is transported via a horse-drawn [limbers and caissons](/wiki/Limbers_and_caissons "Limbers and caissons"). For all other funerals, the casket is transported using a [hearse](/wiki/Hearse "Hearse").
  * Fighter jets in [missing man formation](/wiki/Missing_man_formation "Missing man formation") by the [United States Air Force](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force") may perform an aerial flyover.
  * The formation of a rifle party consisting of an odd number of service members, between 3 and 7, will fire a [three-volley salute](/wiki/Three-volley_salute "Three-volley salute") (size varies according to the rank of the deceased).
  * The playing of _[Taps](/wiki/Taps "Taps")_ is performed by a lone [bugler](/wiki/Bugle "Bugle") or an audio recording, at a distance 30 to 50 yards from the grave site while a “[Final Salute](/wiki/Final_Salute "Final Salute")” is given. (In specific cases with the United States Military Academy, a muffled [drum roll](/wiki/Drum_roll "Drum roll") might accompany the bugler.)

**Full honor** military funerals include all standard honors in addition to
the following:

  * For funerals of [commanding officers](/wiki/Commanding_officer "Commanding officer") of O-6 ([Colonel](/wiki/Colonel_\(United_States\) "Colonel \(United States\)")/[Captain](/wiki/Captain_\(United_States\) "Captain \(United States\)")) and above, a caparisoned, [riderless horse](/wiki/Riderless_horse "Riderless horse"), symbolizing a fallen leader, will follow the limbers and caissons.
  * For funerals of [general officers](/wiki/General_officer "General officer") and [flag officers](/wiki/Flag_officer "Flag officer") of O-10 ([four-star rank](/wiki/Four-star_rank "Four-star rank")), a 17 gun salute is fired; O-9 ([three-star rank](/wiki/Three-star_rank "Three-star rank")), a 15 gun salute is fired; O-8 ([two-star rank](/wiki/Two-star_rank "Two-star rank")), a 13 gun salute is fired; O-7 ([one-star rank](/wiki/One-star_rank "One-star rank")), an 11 gun salute is fired.
  * A [military band](/wiki/United_States_military_bands "United States military bands") and an [escort platoon](/wiki/Platoon "Platoon") participate (size varies according to the rank of the deceased).

**Armed forces** military funerals include all standard and full honors in
addition to the following:

  * Escort platoons from all five branches of the United States Armed Forces participate.
  * These funerals are reserved for the [President of the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States") (as [commander-in-chief](/wiki/Commander-in-chief#United_States "Commander-in-chief")), the [Secretary of Defense](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense "United States Secretary of Defense"), the [Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff](/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff "Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff"), and officers granted multiple-service command.
  * For funerals of presidents, a [21 gun salute](/wiki/21_gun_salute "21 gun salute") using [artillery](/wiki/Artillery_piece "Artillery piece") and [battery pieces](/wiki/Artillery_battery "Artillery battery") is fired (not to be confused with a [three-volley salute](/wiki/Three-volley_salute "Three-volley salute")), while all other high state officials receive 19 gun salutes.

When a spouse or other dependent of a current or former member of the United
States Armed Forces is buried, the military service in which the primary party
served will provide a casket team and a chaplain. No other military honors
will be rendered unless the spouse served in the military.

Members of the [86th Airlift Wing](/wiki/86th_Airlift_Wing "86th Airlift

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Everett_Pope_funeral.jpg/225px-
Everett_Pope_funeral.jpg)](/wiki/File:Everett_Pope_funeral.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Everett_Pope_funeral.jpg "Enlarge")

Inspector General of the Marine Corps Brigadier General Kenneth J. Lee
presents a folded flag to [Laurence E. Pope](/wiki/Laurence_E._Pope "Laurence
E. Pope"), the eldest son of [Medal of Honor](/wiki/Medal_of_Honor "Medal of
Honor") recipient Major [Everett Pope](/wiki/Everett_Pope "Everett Pope")
during the burial service for Major Pope held at Arlington National Cemetery
on September 15, 2009.

The [flag of the United States](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States "Flag of the
United States") draped over the casket is meticulously folded thirteen times
by a total of six honor guards, three on each side of the casket. When the
flag is completely folded, the stars point upwards, which remind Americans of
their [national motto](/wiki/United_States_national_motto "United States
national motto"), _[In God We Trust](/wiki/In_God_We_Trust "In God We
Trust")_.[5][6][_[self-published source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-
published_sources "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_][7] After the flag is completely
folded and tucked in, it takes on the appearance of a [tricorne](/wiki/Bicorne
"Bicorne") hat, reminding Americans of the soldiers who served under General
[George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington"), and the
sailors and Marines who served under Captain [John Paul
Jones](/wiki/John_Paul_Jones "John Paul Jones"), who were followed by their
comrades and shipmates in the United States Armed Forces.[5][6][7]

An honor guard composed of one or more branches of the [United States Armed
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces"),
presents the flag to the [next of kin](/wiki/Next_of_kin "Next of kin"). The
presenter, if possible a member of the same service as the deceased, will
generally kneel while presenting the folded flag, with the straight edge of
the flag facing the recipient. The presenter then recites the following
wording, which was standardized on April 20, 2012:[8]

> On behalf of the President of the United States, the United States (Army,
> Marine Corps, Navy, Air Force or Coast Guard ), and a grateful nation,
> please accept this flag as a symbol of our appreciation for your loved one's
> honorable and faithful service.

Three spent [shell-casings](/wiki/Cartridge_\(firearms\) "Cartridge
\(firearms\)"), each representing one of three volleys, were sometimes slipped
into the folds of the flag before its presentation to the [next of
kin](/wiki/Next_of_kin "Next of kin"). The intention was to convey that the
presence of the shell-casings proved that a rifle volley had taken place in
connection with the members funeral.[9][10] However, this practice has become
infrequent and is rarely seen today as Title 4, Section 8(h) of the [United
States Code](/wiki/United_States_Code "United States Code") specifies that the
flag should not be used as a receptacle for holding anything.[11]

## Ramp
ceremonies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_funerals_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Ramp ceremonies")]

A "ramp ceremony" is a memorial ceremony, not an actual funeral, for a soldier
killed in a war zone held at an airfield near or in a location where an
airplane is waiting nearby to take the deceased's remains to his or her home
country. The term has been in use since about 2005 and became common during
the wars in [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War") and
[Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_\(2001%E2%80%93present\) "War in
Afghanistan \(2001–present\)").[12]
